TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:  Mostly in sinus rhythm with prolonged PR interval,
   frequent PACs and rare PVCs.  Long run of symptomatic VT at 22:23 on
   tele which converted back to SR w/o ICD firing.  5 beats of NSVT at
   2300.  Right groin hematoma stable.  On heparin gtt and Coumadin.  He
   is very anxious and is concerned that he will go back into VT and get
   shocked.  He had difficulty sleeping and required Ambien, Ativan, and
   clonazepam.
   Allergies:
   Monosodium Glutamate
   Palpitations;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 1,300 units/hour
   Lidocaine - 2 mg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Famotidine (Pepcid) - [**2118-8-30**] 10:00 PM

   ABG: ///19/
   Physical Examination
   GENERAL: Pleasant gentleman in NAD, appears comfortable. Oriented x3.
   Mood, affect appropriate.
   HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no
   pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
   NECK: Supple with JVP of 5 cm.
   CARDIAC: PMI displaced laterally, located in 5th intercostal space. S1
   & S2 irregular with a blowing systolic murmur heard best at apex. No
   thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were
   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or
   rhonchi.
   ABDOMEN: Soft, NT/ND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by
   palpation. No abdominial bruits.
   EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. Right thigh hematoma at cath site with borders
   demarcated in marker, no hematoma or bruit of left thigh.
   SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.
   PULSES:
   Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP/PT by Doppler
   Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP/PT by Doppler
   Labs / Radiology
   272 K/uL

        [image002.jpg]
                             [**2118-8-31**]  04:30 AM
   WBC
   11.7
   Hct
   36.5
   Plt
   272
   Cr
   1.1
   Glucose
   107
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:20.7/62.0/1.9, Ca++:8.8 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7
   mg/dL, PO4:3.9 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of some but not all foci
   requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, now on lidocaine
   ggt and amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has [**Month/Year (2) 9226**] and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of some but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT which broke on its own without
   defibrillation
   - Heparin drip with bridge to Coumadin
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - EP today?
   .
   # MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 9226**]: Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral
   valve replacement
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Coumadin restarted after EPS
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - recheck Cr in AM
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna PRN
   -Famotidine
   CODE: Full
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 31**] [**Known lastname 9222**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9227**]; [**Name (NI) 815**] [**Name (NI) 9228**] (Girlfriend)
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9229**]
   DISPO: CCU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Cardiac diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2118-8-30**] 06:33 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2118-8-30**] 06:34 PM
   22 Gauge - [**2118-8-30**] 06:35 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2118-8-31**] 02:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin IV, Coumadin
   Stress ulcer:  famotidine
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: patient and son [**Name (NI) 31**]
   [**Name (NI) 36**] status: Full code
   Disposition: CCU

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) recurrence: The patient has a history of NSVT and has experienced multiple episodes of VT, including a recent run of symptomatic sustained VT. The patient is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone, but there is a risk of VT recurrence.
2. Atrial Fibrillation (AFib) progression: The patient has rate-controlled AFib, and there is a risk of AFib progression to a more severe form.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF) progression: The patient has pre-renal failure likely due to volume depletion, and there is a risk of ARF progression.
4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular events.
5. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) progression: The patient has preserved EF, but there is a risk of HCM progression to a more severe form.
6. Depression/Anxiety: The patient is experiencing anxiety and depression, which may impact his quality of life and increase the risk of cardiovascular events.
7. Thromboembolic events: The patient is at risk of thromboembolic events due to his history of VT and AFib, as well as his use of heparin and Coumadin.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk of infection due to his indwelling catheters and his immunosuppressed state.

To address these potential complications, the patient's treatment plan should include:

1. Monitoring of VT and AFib: The patient should be closely monitored for any changes in his cardiac rhythm, and adjustments should be made to his medications and treatment plan as necessary.
2. Management of ARF: The patient's fluid status should be closely monitored, and measures should be taken to prevent further volume depletion.
3. Management of hyperlipidemia: The patient should be started on aspirin and statins to manage his hyperlipidemia.
4. Management of HCM: The patient's medication regimen should be optimized to manage his HCM.
5. Management of depression/anxiety: The patient should be offered counseling and therapy to manage his depression and anxiety.
6. Thromboembolic prophylaxis: The patient should be continued on heparin and Coumadin to prevent thromboembolic events.
7. Infection prevention: The patient's indwelling catheters should be monitored for signs of infection, and measures should be taken to prevent infection.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone for arrhythmia control. The patient has undergone an electrophysiology study (EPS) with successful ablation of some but not all foci, and has required multiple defibrillations during the procedure.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.4°F)
* Heart rate: 59 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 116/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is on a heparin drip with a goal PTT of 60-100 seconds, and is also receiving amiodarone 400mg TID.

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* A displaced pulse in the 5th intercostal space
* A blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex
* No thrills, lifts, S3, or S4
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 11.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Lidocaine drip at 2mg/min
* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
* Coumadin
* Simvastatin
* Effexor 75mg PO Daily
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (Vfib)
* Atrial fibrillation (AFib)
* Acute renal failure (ARF)
* Hypertension
* Hyperlipidemia
* Depression/anxiety
* Potential bleeding complications due to heparin and Coumadin therapy
* Potential cardiac tamponade due to mitral valve replacement

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
* Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
* Restart Coumadin after EPS
* Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization
* Continue Simvastatin
* Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily
* Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn Sleep
* Monitor for signs of VT, Vfib, and AFib
* Monitor for signs of ARF and adjust fluid management accordingly
* Monitor for signs of bleeding and adjust heparin and Coumadin therapy accordingly
* Monitor for signs of cardiac tamponade and adjust therapy accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure for ventricular tachycardia (VT) and multiple ICD firings. He has a history of NSVT and has been experiencing frequent episodes of VT, including a recent run of symptomatic sustained VT that broke on its own without defibrillation. The patient is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone infusions and is being monitored in the ICU. He is also experiencing atrial fibrillation and has a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and recent episodes of sustained VT increase the risk of further episodes, which could lead to cardiac arrest or death.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's rate-controlled atrial fibrillation may lead to complications such as stroke, embolism, or heart failure.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and urine output may indicate pre-renal failure, which could worsen if not addressed.
4. Anemia: The patient's dropped hematocrit may indicate bleeding or blood loss, which could worsen if not addressed.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may exacerbate his condition and impact his quality of life.
6. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: The patient's history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia may increase his risk of cardiovascular events, such as myocardial infarction or stroke.
8. ICD-Related Complications: The patient's ICD device may be at risk for complications such as infection, lead failure, or inappropriate shocks.

Recommendations:

1. Continue monitoring the patient's VT episodes and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent further episodes.
2. Consider performing an echocardiogram to assess the patient's cardiac function and rule out any structural heart disease.
3. Monitor the patient's creatinine levels and urine output to assess for any signs of worsening kidney function.
4. Consider transfusing blood products to address the patient's anemia.
5. Continue to manage the patient's depression and anxiety with medication and counseling.
6. Consider starting aspirin therapy to reduce the patient's risk of cardiovascular events.
7. Monitor the patient's ICD device for any signs of malfunction or infection.
8. Consider performing a stress test to assess the patient's cardiac function and rule out any signs of coronary artery disease.

   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has [**Month/Year (2) 9226**] and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of some but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT which broke on its own without
   defibrillation
   - Heparin drip with bridge to Coumadin
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   - EP today?
   .
   # MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 9226**]: Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral
   valve replacement
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Coumadin restarted after EPS
   - consider ECHO tomorrow
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%

   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - recheck Cr in AM
   - Monitor UOP
   .

   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple ICD firings. He has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure and is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 59 beats per minute, blood pressure of 116/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He has a right groin hematoma, which is stable, and is on heparin and Coumadin.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He has also been diagnosed with acute renal failure, which is likely due to arrhythmia and volume depletion.

The patient is anxious and concerned about his condition, and has been having difficulty sleeping. He is receiving sedation with Ambien, Ativan, and clonazepam.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and ICD firings increases his risk of recurrent VT, which can lead to cardiac arrest or sudden death.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to stroke, heart failure, and other complications.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure can progress to chronic kidney disease and increase his risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can increase his risk of cardiovascular events, such as heart failure, stroke, and kidney disease.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia can increase his risk of cardiovascular events, such as heart attack and stroke.
6. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, and sudden death.
7. Depression and anxiety: The patient's depression and anxiety can increase his risk of cardiovascular events and worsen his overall health.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lidocaine and amiodarone infusions to manage the patient's VT.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs closely and adjust his medications as needed.
3. Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral valve replacement.
4. Continue Metoprolol to control the patient's atrial fibrillation.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his medications as needed.
6. Consider starting aspirin to reduce the patient's risk of cardiovascular events.
7. Continue Simvastatin to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia.
8. Consider consulting a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiovascular care.

   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of some but not all foci
   requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, now on lidocaine
   ggt and amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has [**Month/Year (2) 9226**] and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of some but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT which broke on its own without
   defibrillation
   - Heparin drip with bridge to Coumadin
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 9226**]: Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral
   valve replacement
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Coumadin restarted after EPS
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - recheck Cr in AM
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna PRN
   -Famotidine

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from the community medical center (CMC) due to repeated episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) resulting in multiple ICD firings. He underwent an unsuccessful ablation procedure and initiation of sotalol to control his heart rate. He was started on lidocaine and amiodarone infusions.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate 59 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure 116/63 mmHg, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute (bpm), and oxygen saturation 96%.
* Heart rhythm: Sinus bradycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs) and rare premature ventricular contractions (PVCs).
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 5 cm, and his cardiac output is stable.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 906 mL of fluid over the past 24 hours, with a total fluid balance of 306 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving nasal cannula oxygen therapy, with an arterial blood gas (ABG) result of pH 7.19.
* Laboratory results: The patient's complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 11.7 K/uL, hemoglobin of 12.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 272 K/uL. His creatinine (Cr) level is 1.1 mg/dL, and his potassium (K) level is 4.4 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia (VT) recurrence: The patient's history of VT and unsuccessful ablation procedure increase the risk of VT recurrence.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of ICD firings and VT episodes increases the risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Renal failure: The patient's current Cr level of 1.1 mg/dL and urine lytes result of 0.6 indicate pre-renal failure, which may worsen if not managed properly.
4. Depression and anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety, as well as his current medication regimen, may increase the risk of depression and anxiety exacerbation.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and lack of aspirin therapy may increase his risk of cardiovascular events.
6. Mitral valve replacement: The patient's history of mitral valve disease and current symptoms of atrial fibrillation may indicate the need for mitral valve replacement surgery.

Based on this information, I recommend the following:

1. Continue lidocaine and amiodarone infusions to control the patient's VT episodes.
2. Monitor the patient's Cr level and urine lytes results to prevent further renal failure.
3. Consider starting aspirin therapy to reduce the patient's risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Refer the patient to a cardiothoracic surgeon for consideration of mitral valve replacement surgery.
5. Continue depression and anxiety management with Effexor, Clonazepam, and Ambien as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust his fluid therapy as needed to prevent fluid overload.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia (VT): The patient has a history of NSVT and has had multiple episodes of VT, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death. The patient is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone, but the arrhythmia is not fully controlled.
2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has increased from 1.4 to 1.2, and urine lytes are ordered. The etiology is likely due to arrhythmia and volume depletion.
3. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease. However, the patient has not been on aspirin due to warfarin dosing.
4. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: The patient has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient has depression and anxiety, which can exacerbate his cardiac condition and increase the risk of arrhythmias.
6. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient is at risk of developing a PE due to his history of VT and immobilization.
7. Sepsis: The patient has a central line and is at risk of developing sepsis.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding due to his history of anticoagulation therapy and the use of antiplatelet agents.

The patient's current medications include:

* Lidocaine drip at 2mg/min
* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
* Coumadin
* Simvastatin
* Effexor 75mg PO Daily
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continuing lidocaine drip and amiodarone
* Continuing Metoprolol and Coumadin
* Considering starting aspirin this hospitalization
* Continuing Simvastatin
* Monitoring urine output and creatinine levels
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and gastrointestinal bleeding
* Considering consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral valve replacement

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and treatment plan. The patient's son has been present during rounds and has been updated on his father's condition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital with a history of sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT) and is currently being treated for VT and atrial fibrillation. The patient has undergone an electrophysiology study (EPS) with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not all foci, requiring multiple defibrillations during the procedure.

The patient's current medications include lidocaine, amiodarone, metoprolol, and coumadin. The patient's laboratory results show a low hematocrit, which is likely due to hemodilution, and a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL, indicating acute renal failure.

The patient's physical examination reveals a pleasant gentleman in no acute distress, with a displaced pulse, a systolic murmur at the apex, and no thrills or lifts. The patient's respiratory examination is unremarkable, with no wheezes or rhonchi.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of sustained VT and the presence of multiple VT foci increases the risk of recurrent VT, which can lead to cardiac arrest.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's rate-controlled atrial fibrillation increases the risk of stroke and thromboembolism.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL indicates acute renal failure, which can progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
4. Anemia: The patient's low hematocrit increases the risk of anemia, which can exacerbate cardiovascular disease.
5. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke.

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is essential to continue monitoring his VT and atrial fibrillation, manage his acute renal failure, and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent complications.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:23.5/88.4/2.2, Ca++:9.1 mg/dL, Mg++:2.1

   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, now on
   lidocaine ggt and amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Continue heparin drip, Coumadin held yesterday
   - Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID up from 50mg PO TID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit continues to drop from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution, but consider CT scan to rule out retroperitoneal
   bleed, will re-check hct at 1300
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Hold Coumadin due to unknown bleeding source
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once anemia resolves
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital after experiencing repeated episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and multiple ICD firings. He underwent an electrophysiology study (EPS) with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not all foci, requiring multiple defibrillations during the procedure.

The patient's current medications include lidocaine drip at 2mg/min, amiodarone 400mg TID, and metoprolol 75mg PO TID. He also has a heparin drip for DVT prophylaxis and is on a cardiac diet.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 62bpm, blood pressure of 127/75mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96% on CPAP. His physical examination is unremarkable, with no signs of congestive heart failure, pulmonary edema, or other significant abnormalities.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Recurrence of ventricular tachycardia: The patient's VT is not fully controlled, and there is a risk of recurrence, which can lead to cardiac arrest or other complications.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has rate-controlled atrial fibrillation, and there is a risk of developing atrial flutter or other atrial arrhythmias.
3. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is decreasing, which may be due to hemodilution or other factors. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of anemia.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, which may be due to pre-renal failure or other factors. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of acute renal failure.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may increase his risk of developing cardiovascular disease.
6. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which may increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Depression/anxiety: The patient is experiencing depression and anxiety, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and complications. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to manage his condition and prevent potential complications.

   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Continue heparin drip, Coumadin held yesterday
   - Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID up from 50mg PO TID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit continues to drop from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution, but consider CT scan to rule out retroperitoneal
   bleed, will re-check hct at 1300
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Hold Coumadin due to unknown bleeding source
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once anemia resolves
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and atrial fibrillation (AF). He was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was started on lidocaine and amiodarone to control his heart rhythm.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 62 beats per minute (bpm) with a range of 45-135 bpm
* Blood pressure: 127/75 mmHg with a range of 89-134/85-99 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute (bpm) with a range of 8-25 bpm
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's physical examination is notable for a displaced pulse, irregular heart rhythm, and a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 11.7 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL
* Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's medications include lidocaine, amiodarone, metoprolol, and simvastatin. He is also receiving heparin and famotidine.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the presence of multiple defibrillations during the ablation procedure increase his risk of recurrent VT.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of AF and the presence of rate-controlled AF on his current medications increase his risk of recurrent AF.
* Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is decreasing, which may be due to hemodilution or a bleeding source. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the anemia.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, which may be due to pre-renal failure or acute tubular necrosis. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the acute renal failure.
* Depression/anxiety: The patient is taking medications for depression and anxiety, and his current mental status is unknown.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue lidocaine and amiodarone to control his heart rhythm
* Increase metoprolol to 75mg PO TID to control his heart rate
* Continue heparin drip to prevent DVT
* Monitor his urine output and creatinine level to assess for acute renal failure
* Consider starting aspirin once his anemia resolves
* Continue simvastatin for hyperlipidemia
* Monitor his mental status and adjust his medications as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement. He has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure and has been experiencing recurrent episodes of VT, including a recent episode that required multiple defibrillations.

The patient is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone infusions, and his ICD has been programmed to an overdrive pace rate of 125. He remains anxious about his heart rhythm and has been experiencing palpitations.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a displaced PMI, irregular S1 and S2, and a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and nontender.

The patient's laboratory results show an anemia with a hematocrit of 33%, likely due to hemodilution. His renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL, and he has pre-renal failure likely due to volume depletion. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medication regimen includes lidocaine, amiodarone, metoprolol, simvastatin, and coumadin. He is also taking aspirin, famotidine, and clonazepam.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and ICD placement puts him at risk for recurrent episodes of VT, which could lead to cardiac arrest or sudden death.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to experience hemodilution, which could lead to decreased oxygen delivery to his tissues.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function may worsen if he continues to experience volume depletion or if his creatinine level increases further.
4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may increase his risk of cardiovascular disease if left untreated.
5. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may worsen if left untreated, leading to cardiac failure or arrhythmias.
6. Depression and anxiety: The patient's depression and anxiety may worsen if left untreated, leading to decreased quality of life and increased risk of cardiac events.

Based on this information, I recommend that the patient's medication regimen be adjusted to include aspirin and clopidogrel to reduce his risk of cardiovascular events. I also recommend that the patient undergo an echocardiogram to assess his cardiac function and rule out any underlying cardiac abnormalities. Additionally, I recommend that the patient be closely monitored for signs of VT, anemia, and acute renal failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and atrial fibrillation (AFib). He was admitted to the ICU after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was found to have two distinct morphologies of VT, one likely coming from the lateral ventricle and one from the mitral valve area. He was started on lidocaine and amiodarone infusions, but continued to experience VT episodes. The patient was also found to have anemia, likely due to hemodilution, and acute renal failure (ARF) likely due to pre-renal failure. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and depression/anxiety.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued VT episodes: The patient's VT episodes may continue to occur, potentially leading to further complications such as cardiac arrest or stroke.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not addressed, potentially leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's ARF may progress if not managed properly, potentially leading to end-stage renal disease or even death.
4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may increase his risk of cardiovascular disease, potentially leading to further cardiac complications.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's depression/anxiety may worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to decreased quality of life and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's VT episodes may lead to cardiac arrest, potentially resulting in brain damage or death.
7. Stroke: The patient's VT episodes may lead to stroke, potentially resulting in permanent neurological damage.
8. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and use of central lines and catheters may increase his risk of infection, potentially leading to sepsis or septic shock.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient's care team continues to monitor his VT episodes and arrhythmias, manages his anemia and ARF, and addresses his hyperlipidemia, depression/anxiety, and other comorbidities.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital due to recurrent episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and sustained VT, despite previous attempts at ablation and medication management. The patient has a history of non-sustained VT and is currently on amiodarone.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 52 bpm (41-69 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 91/45 mmHg (55-124/108-111 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute (10-25 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Sinus bradycardia
* Regular heart rhythm
* Blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex
* No thrills, lifts, S3, or S4
* No chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis
* Unlabored respirations with no accessory muscle use
* Soft, non-tender abdomen with no hepatomegaly or tenderness
* No palpable masses or bruits in the extremities

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 15 mg/dL
* Sodium: 136 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.1 mEq/L
* Chloride: 105 mEq/L
* Carbon dioxide: 35.6%

The patient has several medical conditions, including:

* Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)
* Ventricular tachycardia
* Anemia
* Atrial fibrillation
* Hyperlipidemia
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
* Acute renal failure
* Depression/anxiety

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 75mg PO TID
* Simvastatin
* Coumadin 5mg PO daily
* Heparin IV/coumadin
* Famotidine
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Effexor 75mg PO daily
* Ambien prn sleep
* Tylenol, Fentanyl prn pain management
* Colace, Senna, Miralax bowel regimen

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue amiodarone 400mg TID
* Increase metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
* Start heparin IV as bridge to coumadin 5mg PO daily
* Restart on home CPAP
* Continue simvastatin
* Continue metoprolol
* Monitor urine output and creatinine levels
* Monitor potassium and magnesium levels
* Obtain 12-lead EKG if the patient goes back into VT

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or atrial fibrillation
* Acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease
* Bleeding complications due to heparin or coumadin therapy
* Infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
* Respiratory failure or worsening of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Depression or anxiety exacerbation
* Hyperlipidemia or worsening of hypertriglyceridemia
* Hypertensive crisis or worsening of hypertension
* Acute coronary syndrome or worsening of chronic coronary artery disease

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his medications and treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-inch tall adult admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of palpitations. Over the past 24 hours, their hemoglobin concentration has remained stable, and lidocaine was discontinued. Blood cultures were ordered once. The patient has a history of allergies to monosodium glutamate and is currently receiving various ICU medications and infusions. Their vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 52 bpm, blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's weight is 93.8 kg, and they are receiving fluid support.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 11.7 K/uL, hemoglobin concentration of 11.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 272 K/uL. Their blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 21 mEq/L, creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL, and glucose is 107 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests are within normal limits.

The patient has a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and is currently experiencing ventricular tachycardia. They are receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's current ventricular tachycardia requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.
2. Infection: The patient's blood cultures and laboratory results should be closely monitored for signs of infection, particularly given their history of allergies and current medications.
3. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is negative, indicating a potential risk of fluid overload, which could lead to cardiac or respiratory complications.
4. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutrition plan should be closely monitored to ensure adequate caloric and protein intake to support their recovery.
5. Sleep disturbances: The patient's diagnosis of OSA requires ongoing management and monitoring to prevent further complications, such as respiratory failure or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of allergies and current medications may increase their risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, lab results, and medication regimen.

   Assessment and Plan
 OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA (OSA)
 VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA, SUSTAINED
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, initially
   on lidocaine ggt and amiodarone, now just on amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped [**2118-8-31**]
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Restarted on 3 mg coumadin.  D/C
ed heparin gtt.  INR 2.2 [**2118-9-1**]
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID [**2118-9-1**]
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct stable at 33.4
   -Haptoglobin of 251 which does not support a hemolysis
   - stool guiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.  Currently off as pt
   on coumadin.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin gtt off, pt on home coumadin
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   -Pt states the mask is uncomfortable but the one at home is a better
   fit. Pt was explained the benefits of using his CPAP continuously
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once anemia resolves
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   -Pt is urinating well
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 59-year-old male, was admitted to the ICU with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), ventricular tachycardia (VT), and atrial fibrillation (AFib). He has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure and has been experiencing repeated episodes of VT, resulting in multiple ICD firings.

Currently, the patient is stable, with no complaints overnight and tolerating oral intake. His vital signs are within normal limits, except for a slightly low blood pressure. His heart rhythm remains sinus bradycardia, and his oxygen saturation is 96%.

The patient's physical examination reveals a pleasant gentleman in no acute distress, with a displaced PMI and a blowing systolic murmur at the apex. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

Laboratory results show a stable hemoglobin level, with a slight increase in white blood cell count. His electrolytes and kidney function tests are within normal limits, except for a slight increase in creatinine. His cardiac enzymes and troponin levels are normal.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a history of NSVT with sustained VT episodes and is s/p ICD placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and has been experiencing repeated episodes of VT.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has rate-controlled AFib and is currently on a heparin drip.
3. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33, likely due to hemodilution.
4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of coronary artery disease.
5. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient has a preserved EF of 55-60% and no signs of failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and AFib increases the risk of further arrhythmias, which can lead to cardiac arrest or stroke.
2. Heart failure: The patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and anemia may increase the risk of heart failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to pre-renal failure, which can be exacerbated by his arrhythmias and anemia.
4. Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents increases the risk of bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's use of antibiotics and anticoagulants may increase the risk of infection.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's cardiac rhythm and vital signs.
2. Maintain a low threshold for restarting anticoagulation therapy.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management accordingly.
4. Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once the anemia resolves.
5. Continue metoprolol and amiodarone as prescribed.
6. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust medication as needed.
7. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiology or pulmonary rehabilitation program for further management of his conditions.

I will continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust my recommendations as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea, ventricular tachycardia, and sustained ventricular tachycardia episodes. He was transferred to the ICU after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was started on amiodarone. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate. His oxygen saturation is 96%. The patient is tolerating oral intake and has had a bowel movement. His abdomen is soft and non-tender.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia: The patient's history of sustained ventricular tachycardia episodes and the recent unsuccessful ablation procedure make him at risk for recurrent episodes.
2. Arrhythmia: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the recent episode of sustained ventricular tachycardia make him at risk for further arrhythmia episodes.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's recent episode of acute renal failure and the ongoing use of amiodarone make him at risk for further kidney damage.
4. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety make him at risk for worsening symptoms during his hospital stay.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and the ongoing use of simvastatin make him at risk for further complications related to high cholesterol levels.
6. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: The patient's history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and the ongoing use of metoprolol make him at risk for further complications related to his heart condition.
7. Anemia: The patient's recent drop in hematocrit and the ongoing use of blood transfusions make him at risk for further complications related to anemia.
8. OSA: The patient's history of obstructive sleep apnea and the ongoing use of CPAP make him at risk for further complications related to his sleep disorder.

Recommendations:

1. Continue monitoring the patient's hemodynamic status and arrhythmia episodes.
2. Continue the patient's medication regimen, including amiodarone, metoprolol, and simvastatin.
3. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's mental health and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's sleep quality and adjust his CPAP therapy as needed.
6. Continue to educate the patient and his family on his condition and treatment plan.

   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).

   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required

   - Restarted on 3 mg coumadin.  D/C
ed heparin gtt.  INR ***** this AM.
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID yesterday

   on coumadin.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin gtt off, pt on home coumadin
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), ventricular tachycardia (VT), and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He has been experiencing repeated episodes of VT, resulting in multiple ICD firings, and has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure. He is currently on amiodarone and metoprolol. The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped from 44 to 33, likely due to hemodilution, and his creatinine level has increased to 1.2. He is also experiencing atrial fibrillation and has a history of depression and anxiety.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) Recurrence: Given the patient's history of VT and the fact that he has not been successfully ablated, there is a high risk of VT recurrence.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of VT and ICD firings increases the risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.2, indicating pre-renal failure likely due to volume depletion.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped to 33, which may be a sign of ongoing bleeding or hemodilution.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient has a history of depression and anxiety, and may require further treatment and monitoring.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular events.
7. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: The patient has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue amiodarone and metoprolol to manage VT.
2. Monitor the patient's hemoglobin and creatinine levels closely to detect any changes.
3. Consider starting aspirin to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Continue simvastatin to manage hyperlipidemia.
5. Consider referring the patient to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management.
6. Monitor the patient's mental health and provide appropriate treatment and support.
7. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiothoracic intensive care unit (CTICU) for further management.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and is currently being treated for VT.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 52 bpm, blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His respiratory support includes no oxygen delivery device, and his ABG results are pending.

The patient's physical examination reveals a pleasant gentleman in no acute distress, oriented x3, with a supple neck, no jugular venous distension, and a displaced PMI. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.7 K/μL, hemoglobin of 11.6 g/dL, and hematocrit of 35.6%. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for VT, which has been treated with lidocaine and amiodarone. He has also had an unsuccessful ablation procedure and has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. His medications include amiodarone, metoprolol, and coumadin.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the recent ablation procedure make it likely that he will experience further episodes of VT.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the current presence of rate-controlled atrial fibrillation make it likely that he will experience further episodes of atrial fibrillation.
3. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and the current presence of high cholesterol levels make it likely that he will experience further complications related to hyperlipidemia.
4. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and the current presence of preserved left ventricular function make it likely that he will experience further complications related to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient's history of acute renal failure and the current presence of elevated creatinine levels make it likely that he will experience further complications related to acute renal failure.
6. Depression/anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety and the current presence of these symptoms make it likely that he will experience further complications related to depression and anxiety.

   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, initially
   on lidocaine ggt and amiodarone, now just on amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped [**2118-8-31**]
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Restarted on 3 mg coumadin.  D/C
ed heparin gtt.  INR 1.8 this AM, so
   will need to start heparin IV as bridge to Coumadin 5mg this AM
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID [**2118-9-1**]
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID taper to 400mg [**Hospital1 7**] after one week at
   TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct stable at 33.4
   -Haptoglobin of 251 which does not support a hemolysis
   - stool guaiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has defibrillated back into sinus
   rhythm and will be started on heparin SC with bridge to Coumadin.  Will
   change coumadin dose to 5mg today as INR was subtherapeutic at 1.8 this
   AM.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin IV-> coumadin 5mg
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   -Pt states the mask is uncomfortable but the one at home is a better
   fit. Pt was explained the benefits of using his CPAP continuously
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Hospital1 **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   -Pt is urinating well
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin/ heparin SC
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine
   CODE: Full
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 31**] [**Known lastname 9222**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9227**]; [**Name (NI) 815**] [**Name (NI) 9228**] (Girlfriend)

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and is currently in the ICU after an unsuccessful ablation procedure. He was transferred from another hospital and is being treated for VT, anemia, atrial fibrillation, and acute renal failure. He is on multiple medications, including amiodarone, metoprolol, and heparin, and is being monitored closely for any changes in his condition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia: The patient's VT is a high-risk condition that can lead to cardiac arrest or sudden death if not managed properly. The patient's history of VT and the fact that he has required multiple defibrillations during the ablation procedure increase his risk of VT.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to hemodilution and may worsen if not managed properly. The patient's hemoglobin level is 11.1 g/dL, which is below the normal range.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is a high-risk condition that can increase his risk of stroke and heart failure. The patient's INR is subtherapeutic, which may increase his risk of bleeding.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to arrhythmia and may worsen if not managed properly. The patient's creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL, which is above the normal range.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's depression and anxiety may worsen if not managed properly. The patient is taking medications such as Effexor and Clonazepam, which may have adverse effects on his mental health.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may increase his risk of cardiovascular disease if not managed properly. The patient is taking medications such as Simvastatin, which may help to reduce his cholesterol levels.
7. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: The patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may worsen if not managed properly. The patient's ejection fraction is 55-60%, which is within the normal range.
8. OSA: The patient's OSA may worsen if not managed properly. The patient is using a CPAP machine, which may help to improve his sleep quality.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for various medical complications, including VT, anemia, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, depression/anxiety, hyperlipidemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and OSA. It is essential to monitor the patient closely and manage his conditions properly to reduce his risk of complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure for ventricular tachycardia (VT) and an unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his heart rate. He has a history of NSVT and has been experiencing recurrent episodes of VT, including sustained VT and polymorphic VT. He was started on amiodarone and lidocaine, but the lidocaine drip was stopped due to the patient's VT episodes. An electrophysiology study (EPS) was performed, which showed successful ablation of one VT focus, but not all foci. The patient has also been experiencing atrial fibrillation (AF) and has been started on heparin IV and Coumadin. He has anemia, likely due to hemodilution, and has been started on blood transfusions. He has also been experiencing acute renal failure, which is likely due to his arrhythmias.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and AF, as well as his ongoing arrhythmias, pose a significant risk for further cardiac complications, including sudden cardiac death.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia may lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may lead to further complications, including electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and end-stage renal disease.
4. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and his ongoing arrhythmias may lead to further increases in blood pressure, which may exacerbate his cardiac condition.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may worsen his mental health and quality of life, particularly if his cardiac condition continues to deteriorate.
6. Infection: The patient's ongoing arrhythmias and his presence in the ICU may increase his risk of developing infections, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. Thromboembolic Events: The patient's history of VT and his ongoing arrhythmias may increase his risk of developing thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of hypertension and his ongoing arrhythmias may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition and ongoing arrhythmias pose a significant risk for further complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, initially
   on lidocaine ggt and amiodarone, now just on amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped [**2118-8-31**]
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Went back into A fib yesterday which triggered some non-sustained
   polymorphic VT
   - INR =1.7 this AM, so will need to start heparin IV gtt as bridge to
   Coumadin 5mg.
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID [**2118-9-1**], Diltiazem 30mg QID
   started on [**9-2**]
   - Aggressive magnesium repletion
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID taper to 400mg [**Hospital1 7**] after one week at
   TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct this AM is 35.
   -Haptoglobin of 251 which does not support a hemolysis
   - stool guaiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has defibrillated back into sinus
   rhythm and will be started on heparin IV gtt with bridge to Coumadin.
   Will change coumadin dose to 5mg today as INR was subtherapeutic at 1.7
   this AM.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin IV-> coumadin 5mg
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   -Pt states the mask is uncomfortable but the one at home is a better
   fit. Pt was explained the benefits of using his CPAP continuously
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Hospital1 **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - ARF now resolved, Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   -Pt is urinating well
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   - Ativan PRN for anxiety
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin/ heparin SC
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine
